revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name= Ku-7 Manazuru
Ki-105 Otori |image= Ku-7 glider.jpg |caption= }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type= Transport glider (Ku-7)
Transport aircraft (Ki-105) |national origin= Japan |manufacturer= [[Kokusai]] |designer= |first flight= |introduced= |retired= |status= |primary user= |number built= |developed from= |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Kokusai Ku-7 ''Manazuru''''' (真鶴 "[[white-naped crane]]"; Allied code-name '''Buzzard''') was a large experimental [[twin boom]] Japanese [[military glider]]. ==Design and development== An enlarged version of the earlier [[Maeda Ku-1]] glider, it was developed during 1942. The use of a twin boom design allowed for a large square cargo door, which meant that the aircraft was capable of carrying either 32 soldiers, 7600 kg of cargo or even a [[tankette|light tank]]. It required a powerful towing aircraft, either the [[Nakajima Ki-49]] or the [[Mitsubishi Ki-67]], which were in short supply. As a result, the aircraft were modified by fitting them with engines, which were designated the '''Ki-105 ''Otori''''' (鳳 "[[Phoenix (mythology)|Phoenix]]").{{cite web | last = Donaldson | first = Graham | year=2000 | title = The Japanese paratroopers in the Dutch East Indies, 1941-1942 | url=http://www.dutcheastindies.webs.com/japan_paratroop.html | work = The Netherlands East Indies 1941-1942 }}, access date 29 April 2007. Only nine{{Harvnb|Francillon|1979|p=485.}} were produced before development priorities were shifted elsewhere. ==Variants== *'''Ku-7''': Large experimental military transport glider. *'''Ku-7-II''': Original designation for the Ki-105. *'''Ki-105 Otori''': Longe-range fuel tanker aircraft. Powered version. Nine built. ==Specifications (Ku-7)== {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?= plane |jet or prop?= |ref=''Encyklopedia Uzbrojenia'';{{cite web|url=http://www.dws.xip.pl/bron/japonia/j58.html |last=Skrzypacz |first=Marcin |year=2005 |title="Kokusai Ku-7 "Manazuru" in ''Encyklopedia Uzbrojenia'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517060508/http://www.dws.xip.pl/bron/japonia/j58.html |archivedate=May 17, 2008 }} via archive.org ''Japanese Aircraft of the Pacific War'' |crew= two |capacity= 32 passengers or 8000kg of supplies or an 8-ton [[tankette|light tank]]. |length main= 19.92 m |length alt= 65 ft 4¼ in |span main= 35.0 m |span alt= 114 ft 10 in |height main= |height alt= |area main= 100.37 m2 |area alt= 1080 ft2 |airfoil= |empty weight main= 3,536 kg |empty weight alt= 7,800 lb |loaded weight main= 12,000 kg |loaded weight alt= 26,455 lb |useful load main= 7,664 kg |useful load alt= 16,900 lb |max takeoff weight main= 11,000 kg |max takeoff weight alt= 24,250 lb |more general= |max speed main= |max speed alt= |max speed more= |cruise speed main= 220 km/h |cruise speed alt= 108 kn, 125 mph |cruise speed more= |never exceed speed main= 355 km/h |never exceed speed alt= 192 kn, 220 mph |stall speed main= |stall speed alt= |range main= |range alt= |ceiling main= |ceiling alt= |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= |loading alt= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= |armament= |avionics= }} ==See also== {{aircontent |related= |similar aircraft= * [[Gotha Go 242]] |lists= |see also= }} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|2}} ;Bibliography {{refbegin}} * Francillon, Ph.D., René J. ''Japanese Aircraft of the Pacific War''. London: Putnam & Company Ltd., 1970 (2nd edition 1979). (2005) "Kokusai Ku-7 "Manazuru" in Encyklopedia Uzbrojenia] via http://www.dws.xip.pl, accessdate 30 April 2007 * [http://airwiki.org/enc/glider/ku7.html Ku.7 Manazuru] via http://airwiki.org, accessdate 30 April 2007 (in Russian) {{Kokusai aircraft}} {{Japanese Army Aircraft Designation System}} {{Japanese Army Glider Designation System}} {{Allied reporting names}} [[Category:Kokusai aircraft|Ku-07]] [[Category:Japanese military transport aircraft 1940–1949|Ku-07, Kokusai]] [[Category:Glider aircraft]] [[Category:World War II Japanese transport aircraft]] [[Category:High-wing aircraft]]
